docs.snippet: The men of "Ego Trip's Race-O-Rama," a new VH1 series that takes an irreverent look at race in pop culture, have little problem discussing the dreaded R-word....
docs.lead_paragraph: Gabriel Alvarez, a hip-hop journalist of Mexican descent, has a theory about race in America. ''It's the new pornography,'' he declared one recent afternoon. ''It's the only thing in our culture that people are still uncomfortable talking about.'' But Mr. Alvarez and his friends, the music writers Sacha Jenkins and Jefferson Mao; Elliott Wilson, the editor in chief of XXL, the hip-hop magazine; and Brent Rollins, a graphic designer, have little problem discussing the dreaded R-word. In fact, it is one of the favorite topics of conversation for this five-man collective, which calls itself Ego Trip.
docs.abstract: Article on Ego Trip, five-man collective made up of hip-hop journalist Gabriel Alvarez, music writers Sacha Jenkins and Jefferson Mao, XXL magazine editor Elliott Wilson and graphic designer Brent Rollins; members comment on Ego Trip's Race-O-Rama, new VH1 series that takes irreverent look at race in pop culture; photo (M)

docs.snippet: Renée Fleming offered her perfectly tuned voice, agility and deep attention to an evening of songs and arias on Monday at Carnegie Hall....
docs.lead_paragraph: A subtitle to Renée Fleming's evening of songs and arias on Monday might have read, ''This is not a diva recital.'' Ms. Fleming is a lionized citizen of operadom, and this was Carnegie Hall, but serious purpose by the American soprano was everywhere: Purcell, Handel, Berg and Schumann for her to sing, and to play alongside, a fully staffed Baroque ensemble called Rebel, and Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau's former accompanist Hartmut Höll. Diva recitals are duets between beloved stars and their adoring fans: signature sounds from the stage, howls of appreciation from out front. Music is a pretext. Diva recitals might use a little early music to clear the throat, but would not later on devote Ms. Fleming's kind of care to Berg's seven early songs and eight more by Schumann.
docs.abstract: Bernard Holland reviews recital by soprano Renee Fleming and Baroque ensemble called Rebel; photo (M)

docs.snippet: "I don't want to speak to a reporter if they don't know I'm in the movie!" Cicely Tyson yelled at the premiere of "Diary of a Mad Black Woman."...
docs.lead_paragraph: We Brake For Stark Naked Romantics ''I don't want to speak to a reporter if they don't know I'm in the movie!'' CICELY TYSON yelled at one of the publicists at the premiere of ''Diary of a Mad Black Woman'' in Hollywood on Monday night. Ms. Tyson does not star in the film, and the hapless TV scribe standing nearby had yet to see it.
docs.abstract: Joyce Wadler column on premiere of movie Diary of a Mad Black Woman in Hollywood (M)

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: DIARY OF A MAD BLACK WOMAN (MOVIE)

byline.original: By Joyce Wadler; With David Jay Lasky in Los Angeles

docs.snippet: Mexican officials answer to people at home who cast ballots and the ones abroad who pull the purse strings....
docs.lead_paragraph: Less than two months after he was elected, Mayor Alberto Ruiz Flores climbed in his truck and set out on a 26-hour road trip across the border to Southern California, carrying a wish list of public works projects to a backyard barbecue in Oxnard. The reason? To solicit money from some of the 400,000 Mexicans who abandon their country each year for work in the United States, including half his town in Central Mexico. Those who have left Valparaíso send home an estimated $100,000 a day, as much money in one month as the municipality will spend all year.
docs.abstract: Financial remittances sent home by Mexican migrants working in United States, both legal and illegal, as well as those from other places in Central America and Caribbean, are being translated into political clout in their home communities; migrants' communities in United States are better organized and more vocal than before and have become social and political forces too important to ignore at home; half the people of Valparaiso, Mexico, have left to work in United States, sending home an estimated $100,000 a day, as much money in one month as municipality will spend all years; Mayor Alberto Ruiz Flores travels to places like Oxnard, Calif, and Aurora, Ill, to solicit funds for public works projects in Valparaiso; in addition, countries like Mexico and Dominican Republic are taking steps to allow their citizens living in United States to cast absentee ballots in elections; map shows amount of remittances sent from various US states, to various places in Mexico; photos (L)

headline.main: Mexico's Migrants Profit From Dollars Sent Home

docs.snippet: Sometimes the language of translation is as revealing as it is goofy....
docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes the language of translation is as revealing as it is goofy. The Camera Nazionale della Moda, Italy's foremost fashion trade group, announced that more than 10,000 ''fashion operators'' would converge here for the start today of fall 2005 Fashion Week. Among the operators on hand to take part in 93 fashion shows and 150 other presentations -- some important to the world of style, some notable for their appalling lack of it (one company has set up a showroom to pitch a line of clothing made from the hides of baby elephants) -- are a lot of the usual suspects. There are the customary platoons of editors, buyers and models (along with their scruffy boyfriends/leeches), as well as 1,700 journalists microscopically dissecting the varied goings-on. One group is missing from Milan this week, and even this early in the proceedings its absence can be felt. Its members are the stylists, those peripatetic and generally mysterious people whose job description is so difficult to pin down. With the Academy Awards less than a week away, many top stylists have opted for Los Angeles over Milan. Oscar, or Grammy, trumps Prada any day.
docs.abstract: Guy Trebay Fashion Diary on fashion designers who support legions of stars attending large award ceremonies; some pass up 2005 Fashion Week in Milan to attend Academy Awards; photo (M)

docs.snippet: In the scramble for Oscar votes, the publicity campaigns for films like "Vera Drake" and "Hotel Rwanda" have made use, with some mixed feelings, of the issues the movies address....
docs.lead_paragraph: As audience members walked into the Avalon Theater here Wednesday night, they passed a refreshment counter offering popcorn and candy and a folding table offering brochures and condoms. But this was not unusual for a private screening of ''Vera Drake,'' the British director Mike Leigh's film about a good-natured London woman in 1950 who breaks the law by performing abortions. Groups that promote abortion rights, like Planned Parenthood Federation of America, which sponsored the showing, have embraced the movie as a cautionary tale for women, should the Supreme Court overturn Roe v. Wade, the case that made abortion legal in the United States.
docs.abstract: Oscar-nominated films that deal with social issues like abourtion (Vera Drake), mass killings (Hotel Rwanda) and assisted suicide (The Sea Inside and Million Dollar Baby) are being promoted by outside groups concerned about those issues, enabling films to gain attention without violating academy rules that bar direct solicitation of Oscar voters; photos (M)

headline.main: Social Issues Fuel Race for Oscar

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: WAR CRIMES, GENOCIDE AND CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY

docs.snippet: Pronunciation researcher Paul Topping of Recorded Books has become an authority on foreign expressions, medical maladies and fictional languages....
docs.lead_paragraph: As a researcher at Recorded Books, the audiobook publisher, Paul Topping hunts for precise pronunciations of foreign expressions, medical maladies and obscure geographical and biological names. In his quest, he might consult his scores of reference books, conduct Internet research and telephone anyone from Alaskan librarians to C.I.A. officers to Antigua restaurateurs to the authors themselves. Ultimately Mr. Topping, who works in the Manhattan studios of the 26-year-old Maryland-based company, writes the words out phonetically to guide narrators as they record books. He has been nailing pronunciations for more than two decades, but in the painstaking process still spends many hours just hammering his thumb.
docs.abstract: Paul Topping, pronunciation expert at Recorded Books, writes words out phonetically to guide narrators as they record books; comments on mispronounced words he has heard, his work on Chakobsa, fictitious language from Frank Herbert's science-fiction series Dune, his handwritten archived guides for narrators and hoped-for megalog of researched words in searchable database; photos (M)

docs.snippet: A King alto saxophone that belonged to Charlie Parker and a Thelonious Monk high school notebook were among the top draws at a Manhattan auction of jazz memorabilia....
docs.lead_paragraph: The serious bidding got under way quickly at the big jazz auction yesterday afternoon, at Jazz at Lincoln Center's Rose Theater. The auction was front-loaded with Louis Armstrong items, and the first lot contained a four-page handwritten letter from Louis Armstrong to his booking agent Joe Glaser, asking about the possibility of a gig in a Broadway theater: $3,500. An Armstrong telegram to Mr. Glaser about dental problems and a lack of cash: $1,600. The awesome lot No. 10, a bawdy 32-page handwritten letter to Armstrong's manager, Oscar Cohen: $25,000.
docs.abstract: Jazz artifacts are auctioned off in Jazz at Lincoln Center's Rose Theater in Time Warner Center; Guernsey's, auction house, suggests that winning bidders consider donating items to Smithsonian's American Music Collections when they no longer want them (M)

headline.main: Jazz Enthusiasts Pick Up A Few Lingering Echoes

byline.original: By BEN RATLIFF; Colin Moynihan contributed reporting for this article

docs.snippet: Audiences loved Paul Giamatti as Miles in the winecentric "Sideways," but some say the movie ignores alcoholism....
docs.lead_paragraph: MILES, the protagonist of the Oscar-nominated film ''Sideways,'' may be all thumbs when it comes to writing and women, but when the subject is wine, he is a poet of pinot noirs and just about every other grape he meets on an alcohol-fueled road trip through the Santa Barbara wine country. In between swirls, tastings and lyrical wine epiphanies, however, this same merlot-phobic sophisticate is shown stumbling blindly out of a bar, chugging wine straight from the bottle, and, at his most desperate, doing the unimaginable: guzzling from the spit bucket.
docs.abstract: Some alcohol treatment professionals express concern that issue of alcoholism is ignored in popular and intellectually alluring movie Sideways, which is nominated for five Academy Awards; contend that main character's trials and tribulations throughout movie, while funny, are also indications that he is an alcoholic, and allege that viewers, dangerously, are not reading him in this light;photos (M)

headline.main: Is a Wine-Soaked Film Too, Er, Rosé?

docs.snippet: The city always puts on a show, but never as gaudy as for the Academy Awards....
docs.lead_paragraph: Why Go Now The historian Carey McWilliams once said that being in Los Angeles was like having a ''ringside seat at the circus.'' Never is that truer than during the entertainment industry's high holy days -- the awards season -- which culminate in the 77th annual Academy Awards at the Kodak Theater on Feb. 27.
docs.abstract: Sally Horchow travel article on visiting Los Angeles, Hollywood, Beverly Hills and West Hollywood, Calif, during annual Academy Awards season; photos; map (M)

headline.main: Paying Homage to Hollywood's High Holy Days
